topics.title: Why Dryer Lint Is So Dangerous

hook.text: Dryer lint causes 2,900 house fires in the US every year. It's one of the most flammable materials in your home.

buildup.text: Lint is tiny loose fibers with enormous surface area relative to mass. More surface area means faster ignition.

discovery.text: When lint clogs the dryer vent, exhaust heat has nowhere to go. Temperatures climb past lint's ignition point of 210Â°C.

twist.text: Campers use dryer lint as a firestarter because it ignites instantly. That's the same stuff inside your walls.

climax.text: Cleaning the lint trap isn't enoughâ€”lint builds up inside the vent duct behind the dryer where you can't see it.

punchline.text: The best firestarter hides behind your dryer.

quiz.question: Why is dryer lint so flammable?
options: It has enormous surface area relative to its mass
It contains highly flammable chemical dyes
It generates static electricity that sparks

hook.text: Every fire needs exactly three things: heat, fuel, and oxygen. Remove any one and the fire dies instantly.

buildup.text: This is the fire triangle. Firefighters don't just spray waterâ€”they strategically remove one side of the triangle.

discovery.text: Water cools (removes heat). Foam smothers (removes oxygen). Firebreaks clear vegetation (remove fuel).

twist.text: Your kitchen has all three in abundance: gas or electric heat, cooking oil as fuel, and open air for oxygen.

climax.text: Fire extinguishers are labeled A/B/C for different fuels. Using the wrong one on a grease fire makes it explode.

punchline.text: Three ingredients create every fire on Earth.

quiz.question: What are the three elements of the fire triangle?
options: Heat, fuel, and oxygen
Flame, smoke, and spark
Wood, gas, and electricity

topics.title: Why Grease Fires Explode with Water

hook.text: Pouring water on a grease fire doesn't put it out. It creates a fireball that can engulf an entire kitchen in seconds.

buildup.text: Cooking oil burns at 300Â°C+. Water boils at 100Â°C. When water hits hot oil, it vaporizesâ€”expanding 1,700 times.

discovery.text: The steam explosion atomizes burning oil into a fine mist. Each tiny droplet ignites, creating a massive fireball.

twist.text: A single cup of water on a small grease fire can produce a fireball reaching the ceiling and spreading across the room.

climax.text: The correct response: smother with a lid, use baking soda, or use a Class B fire extinguisher. Never move the pan.

punchline.text: Water is fire's ally in a grease fire.

quiz.question: Why does water cause a grease fire to explode?
options: Water instantly vaporizes in hot oil, atomizing it into a burning mist
Water chemically reacts with grease to produce hydrogen gas
Water conducts heat, spreading the fire to surrounding materials

topics.title: Smoke Detectors and the Two-Minute Rule

hook.text: In a modern home, you have about two minutes to escape a fire. In 1970, you had seventeen. What changed?

buildup.text: Older homes had solid wood furniture that burned slowly. Today's synthetic materialsâ€”foam, polyesterâ€”burn 8x faster.

discovery.text: Synthetics also produce toxic fumes. Most fire deaths aren't from burns but from inhaling carbon monoxide and cyanide.

twist.text: Ionization detectors catch fast-flaming fires. Photoelectric ones catch slow smoldering. You need both types.

climax.text: Smoke detectors cut your risk of dying in a fire by 50%. Yet 25% of homes have non-working detectors.

punchline.text: Two minutes. That's all modern fire gives you.

quiz.question: Why do modern homes give less escape time in fires?
options: Synthetic materials burn up to 8 times faster than solid wood
Modern homes have more rooms and longer escape routes
Air conditioning systems spread fire through ductwork

hook.text: A dry Christmas tree can fully ignite a room in 30 seconds. Fire departments film this annually, and it's terrifying.

buildup.text: Dry pine needles are essentially kindling. A tree that hasn't been watered for a week is a seven-foot column of fuel.

discovery.text: Flashover hits when everything in a room reaches ignition temperature from radiant heat at once. Escape is impossible.

twist.text: A watered tree barely burnsâ€”needles steam instead of igniting. The only gap between safety and disaster is water.

climax.text: LED lights reduced ignition risk by 90% over incandescent bulbs, but dry trees remain the primary holiday fire hazard.

punchline.text: The difference between festive and fatal is a cup of water.

quiz.question: What is flashover in fire terminology?
options: When everything in a room simultaneously reaches ignition temperature
When a fire reaches the ceiling and flashes across it
When a fire spreads from one floor to another

hook.text: Carbon monoxide has no color, no smell, no taste. Without an alarm you can't detect it. It kills 400+ Americans yearly.

buildup.text: CO is produced by incomplete combustionâ€”gas furnaces, stoves, fireplaces, and cars running in attached garages.

discovery.text: CO binds to hemoglobin 230 times more tightly than oxygen. It steals your blood's ability to carry oxygen to your brain.

twist.text: Symptoms mimic the flu: headache, dizziness, nausea. Many victims assume they're sick and lie down instead of fleeing.

climax.text: A $30 CO detector is the only protection. It should be on every floor, especially near bedrooms and gas appliances.

punchline.text: The deadliest gas is the one you can't sense.

quiz.question: Why is carbon monoxide so dangerous to humans?
options: It binds to hemoglobin 230x more tightly than oxygen
It causes explosive reactions in the lungs
It dissolves the lining of the respiratory tract

topics.title: Radon: The Radioactive Gas Under Your House

hook.text: Radon is the second-leading cause of lung cancer after smoking. It seeps in through the groundâ€”odorless and invisible.

buildup.text: Radon forms naturally from uranium decaying in soil and rock. It's a noble gasâ€”colorless, odorless, chemically inert.

discovery.text: It enters through foundation cracks, gaps around pipes, and sump pits. Basements trap it at concentrated levels.

twist.text: 1 in 15 US homes has dangerous radon levels. The only way to know is a $15 test kit from any hardware store.

climax.text: Mitigation is simple: a vent pipe and fan pulls radon from under the foundation and exhausts it above the roof safely.

punchline.text: A $15 test could save your lungs.

quiz.question: How does radon enter most homes?
options: Through foundation cracks and gaps around pipes from the soil below
Through the municipal water supply
Through air conditioning ducts from outside

hook.text: Asbestos was the 'miracle mineral'â€”fireproof, cheap, everywhere. It was in 3,000+ products before the cancer link.

buildup.text: From the 1920s to 1980s, asbestos filled insulation, floor tiles, ceiling textures, pipe wrapping, and brake pads.

discovery.text: Asbestos fibers are micro-sharp and barbed. Once inhaled, they pierce lung tissue and the body cannot expel them.

twist.text: Intact asbestos is safe. It turns deadly when disturbedâ€”drilling, sanding, or demolishing releases the fibers.

climax.text: Millions of homes still hold asbestos. Pro removal costs thousands, but DIY abatement is illegal in many states.

punchline.text: The miracle mineral became a silent epidemic.

quiz.question: When does asbestos become dangerous in a home?
options: When it's disturbed by drilling, sanding, or demolition
As soon as it's installed in any form
When it gets wet from water damage

topics.title: Lead Paint and the Childhood IQ Crisis

hook.text: Homes built before 1978 likely contain lead paint. When it chips and becomes dust, children eat and inhale it.

buildup.text: Lead damages the developing brain for life. Even low exposure cuts IQ, causes behavioral issues, and impairs learning.

discovery.text: Lead paint tastes sweetâ€”children are attracted to paint chips. Toddlers who mouth windowsills ingest the highest doses.

twist.text: Sanding or scraping lead paint without containment creates toxic dust that persists in carpets and soil for decades.

climax.text: Painting over lead paint encapsulates it safely. Removal is riskier than sealing unless the surface is crumbling.

punchline.text: Sweet-tasting paint stole IQ points for decades.

quiz.question: Why are young children especially vulnerable to lead paint?
options: They mouth surfaces, and lead paint chips taste sweet
Their skin absorbs lead at a higher rate than adults
They spend more time outdoors near exterior paint

topics.title: Off-Gassing: When New Things Smell Toxic

hook.text: That 'new carpet smell' is volatile organic compounds evaporating into your air. It's not freshnessâ€”it's chemicals.

buildup.text: VOCs include formaldehyde, benzene, and toluene. They off-gas from paints, adhesives, foam, plywood, and fabrics.

discovery.text: Indoor air can be 2-5x more polluted than outdoor air. New construction and renovations spike VOC levels fast.

twist.text: Most off-gassing happens in the first 72 hours. Opening windows for three days after new materials slashes exposure.

climax.text: Low-VOC and zero-VOC paints, adhesives, and flooring now exist. Labels like GREENGUARD verify the claim.

punchline.text: If your new room smells fresh, ventilate it fast.

quiz.question: When does most off-gassing from new materials occur?
options: Within the first 72 hours after installation
Gradually over the first five years
Only when exposed to direct sunlight

hook.text: A single outlet is rated for 15 amps. Plug in a space heater, hair dryer, and toaster, and you've tripled the safe load.

buildup.text: Every wire has resistance. When current exceeds the rating, resistance generates heatâ€”wires inside your walls get hot.

discovery.text: Breakers should trip before wires overheat. But loose connections and corrosion can delay the trip just long enough.

twist.text: Extension cords don't add circuit capacityâ€”they just let you plug in more devices than the wiring can handle.

climax.text: Electrical fires kill 300+ Americans yearly. Most start inside walls where hot wires touch insulation or wood.

punchline.text: More plugs don't mean more power.

quiz.question: What happens when you exceed an outlet's rated amperage?
options: Wire resistance generates heat that can ignite wall materials
The outlet immediately shuts off to protect the circuit
The connected devices simply run at reduced power

topics.title: GFCIs Save Lives in Wet Areas

hook.text: Before GFCIs, about 800 people died from electrocution at home each year in the US. Now it's under 200.

buildup.text: A GFCI monitors current flowing out and back through a circuit. The two values should be exactly equal.

discovery.text: If even 5 milliamps leaks through your body to groundâ€”like through wet handsâ€”the GFCI cuts power in 1/40th of a second.

twist.text: GFCIs have test buttons, but only 5% of homeowners press them monthly as recommended. Worn GFCIs fail silently.

climax.text: Code requires GFCIs in bathrooms, kitchens, garages, and outdoors. Homes without them face 4x the electrocution risk.

punchline.text: Five milliamps of difference saves your life.

quiz.question: How does a GFCI protect against electrocution?
options: It detects current leaking to ground and cuts power instantly
It limits the total voltage at the outlet
It prevents water from reaching the wiring

topics.title: Arc Faults: Fires from Bad Wiring

hook.text: An electrical arc is a spark jumping a gap in damaged wiring. It burns at 6,000Â°Câ€”hot enough to ignite wood fast.

buildup.text: Arcs happen when wire insulation degrades, nails pierce cables, or connections loosen inside walls over time.

discovery.text: Arc Fault Circuit Interrupters (AFCIs) detect the unique electrical signature of an arc and shut down the circuit.

twist.text: Standard breakers only protect against overcurrentâ€”they ignore arcing entirely. A 1-amp arc can start a fire.

climax.text: AFCIs are now required in bedrooms, living rooms, and hallways in new builds. Older homes have no arc protection.

punchline.text: A spark you can't see at 6,000Â°C inside your wall.

quiz.question: Why can't standard circuit breakers prevent arc-caused fires?
options: They only detect overcurrent, not the low-amperage arcing signature
They respond too slowly to momentary arcs
They're only designed for kitchen and bathroom circuits

hook.text: Homes wired with aluminum in the 1960s-70s are 55 times more likely to have fire-hazard electrical connections.

buildup.text: Copper prices spiked during the Vietnam War. Builders switched to cheaper aluminum wire for 2 million US homes.

discovery.text: Aluminum expands and contracts more than copper when heated. Over years, connections loosen at outlets and switches.

twist.text: Aluminum corrodes where it touches copper, creating high-resistance junctions that glow red-hot inside walls.

climax.text: Rewiring is ideal but costs $10,000+. COPALUM connectors safely join aluminum to copper devices at a fraction.

punchline.text: A wartime cost-cut haunts millions of homes.

quiz.question: Why is aluminum wiring more dangerous than copper?
options: It expands more when heated, loosening connections over time
It conducts electricity at dangerously high voltages
It dissolves in moisture, causing short circuits

hook.text: A metal bathtub and a pipe two feet apart can carry different voltages. Touch both while wet and the current kills.

buildup.text: Faulty wiring, lightning, or utility faults can energize metal objects in your home at different voltage levels.

discovery.text: Equipotential bonding ties all metal objects in a bathroom to one groundâ€”erasing voltage differences between them.

twist.text: Plastic pipes broke the bonding chain in modern plumbing. New code requires separate bonding wires to compensate.

climax.text: Most older bathrooms lack proper bonding. A simple copper wire connecting fixtures to the ground system fixes the risk.

punchline.text: Equal voltage everywhere means zero shock risk.

quiz.question: What does equipotential bonding in a bathroom prevent?
options: Voltage differences between metal objects that could cause electrocution
Water from conducting electricity through pipes
Static electricity buildup on metal surfaces

hook.text: Mold spores are everywhereâ€”in every breath you take. They just need 48 hours of moisture to start colonizing your walls.

buildup.text: A leak, condensation, or humidity above 60% supplies enough water. Drywall paper and wood are ideal food sources.

discovery.text: Mold grows inside walls and under floors firstâ€”by the time you see it on a surface, the colony behind it is much larger.

twist.text: Bleach kills surface mold but can't reach roots embedded in porous materials. It often grows back worse in weeks.

climax.text: The only real fix is removing moisture. Without water, existing mold goes dormant and new spores can't germinate.

punchline.text: Mold doesn't need an invitationâ€”just moisture.

quiz.question: Why does bleach often fail to permanently remove mold?
options: It can't reach the root hyphae embedded in porous materials
Mold spores are resistant to bleach chemicals
Bleach evaporates too quickly to kill mold

hook.text: That beautiful row of icicles on your roof is actually a sign of damage happening right now above your head.

buildup.text: Heat leaking through a poorly insulated attic melts roof snow. Water runs down to the colder eaves and refreezes.

discovery.text: The ice dam blocks further meltwater, which pools behind it. Standing water seeps under shingles and into your ceiling.

twist.text: Chopping ice off treats the symptom but damages shingles. The real fix is air-sealing and insulating the attic.

climax.text: A well-insulated attic stays cold in winterâ€”matching outside temperature. No heat loss means no melting and no ice dams.

punchline.text: Pretty icicles mean your attic is failing.

quiz.question: What actually causes ice dams on a roof?
options: Heat escaping through the attic melts snow that refreezes at the eaves
Frozen gutters that prevent water drainage
Heavy snowfall that compresses into ice layers

hook.text: Sixty percent of US basements get wet. The cause is almost never plumbingâ€”it's the ground itself pushing water in.

buildup.text: Soil around foundations absorbs rain like a sponge. As hydrostatic pressure builds, water pushes through any crack.

discovery.text: Solid concrete is slightly porous. Water vapor migrates through basement walls nonstop, especially in wet seasons.

twist.text: Most basement flooding is fixed outside: grade soil away from the foundation and extend downspouts. That solves 90%.

climax.text: Sump pumps handle the remaining 10%. A battery backup is essentialâ€”power outages and heavy storms happen simultaneously.

punchline.text: Water comes from outside. Fix the outside first.

quiz.question: What causes most basement flooding?
options: Hydrostatic pressure from groundwater pushing through foundation cracks
Failed plumbing connections below the floor
Rising water tables from climate change

topics.title: The Danger of Stagnant Water in Pipes

hook.text: Water sitting in pipes for just 6 hours can grow Legionella bacteria to dangerous levels. It thrives between 25-45Â°C.

buildup.text: Legionella causes Legionnaires' diseaseâ€”a severe pneumonia caught by inhaling tainted droplets from taps or showers.

discovery.text: Dead legsâ€”unused pipe sectionsâ€”are breeding grounds. Guest baths, unused sinks, and vacation homes are high risk.

twist.text: Hot water tanks set below 60Â°C incubate Legionella perfectly. Many heaters are factory-set at 49Â°C to prevent scalding.

climax.text: Flush unused taps weekly and keep water heaters at 60Â°C+. Simple habits eliminate most Legionella risk.

punchline.text: Still water doesn't just get staleâ€”it gets deadly.

quiz.question: At what temperature range does Legionella bacteria thrive?
options: Between 25Â°C and 45Â°C
Below 10Â°C in cold water
Above 70Â°C in very hot water

hook.text: A pinhole leak in a pipe wastes 2,000 gallons per year. But the water damage costs 100 times more than the water itself.

buildup.text: Slow leaks saturate drywall, rot wood framing, and create mold coloniesâ€”all invisible behind finished walls.

discovery.text: Warning signs: unexplained musty smells, bubbling paint, warm floor spots (from hot-water leaks), or a water bill spike.

twist.text: Insurance often denies gradual leak claims, covering only 'sudden and accidental' damage. Slow leaks are on you.

climax.text: Smart leak sensors cost under $30. Under sinks, near water heaters, or in basements, they alert your phone instantly.

punchline.text: The leak you can't see costs the most.

quiz.question: Why do insurance companies often deny claims for hidden pipe leaks?
options: They typically only cover sudden and accidental damage, not gradual leaks
Hidden leaks are considered a pre-existing condition
The damage usually costs less than the deductible

hook.text: Nearly every concrete foundation cracks. Most are harmless shrinkage. A few are warning signs of structural failure.

buildup.text: Concrete shrinks as it cures, creating hairline cracks in the first year. These are cosmetic and rarely grow wider.

discovery.text: Horizontal cracks signal lateral pressure from soil or waterâ€”the wall is being pushed inward. That's serious.

twist.text: Stair-step cracks in block foundations follow mortar joints. They signal differential settlingâ€”one side is sinking.

climax.text: A structural engineer costs $300-$500 and can save hundreds of thousands in damage by catching problems early.

punchline.text: Vertical cracks: usually fine. Horizontal: act now.

quiz.question: Which type of foundation crack indicates the most serious structural problem?
options: Horizontal cracks from lateral soil or water pressure
Vertical hairline cracks from concrete shrinkage
Diagonal cracks near window corners

hook.text: Termites cause $5 billion in property damage in the US every yearâ€”more than fires, floods, and tornadoes combined.

buildup.text: Subterranean termites live underground and build mud tubes up foundations to reach wood. Colonies top a million.

discovery.text: They eat wood from the inside out. A beam can look solid but be completely hollowâ€”you discover it when a wall collapses.

twist.text: Homeowners insurance won't cover termite damageâ€”it's classed as preventable maintenance, making it all your cost.

climax.text: Annual inspections cost $75-$150. Catching termites early saves the average homeowner over $8,000 in structural repairs.

punchline.text: They eat your house, and insurance won't pay.

quiz.question: Why is termite damage typically not covered by homeowners insurance?
options: It's classified as preventable through regular maintenance
The damage is usually cosmetic, not structural
Termite colonies are considered an act of nature

topics.title: Load-Bearing Walls You Must Never Remove

hook.text: Renovation shows make knocking down walls look fun. Remove the wrong one and your second floor drops into the first.

buildup.text: Load-bearing walls carry everything aboveâ€”roof, floors, furnitureâ€”down to the foundation in a continuous chain.

discovery.text: Clues: walls perpendicular to joists, walls under the ridgeline, and walls that stack vertically floor to floor.

twist.text: Load-bearing walls can be removed, but only with a properly sized beam or header. The math must be exact.

climax.text: An undersized beam won't fail at once. It sags over months, cracking drywall and jamming doors until the floor gives.

punchline.text: Every wall holds something. Know what before swinging.

quiz.question: What must be installed to safely remove a load-bearing wall?
options: A properly sized beam or header engineered for the load
A pair of support columns on each end
Reinforced drywall with steel backing plates

topics.title: Why Old Houses Sag in the Middle

hook.text: If a marble rolls to the center of your floor, your house has a sagging problem. It's incredibly common in older homes.

buildup.text: Floor joists span wall to wall. Without a center beam, gravity slowly deflects them downward in the middle.

discovery.text: Wood beams also creepâ€”they slowly deform under constant load. A beam that was straight in 1940 may bow 2 inches by 2024.

twist.text: Sagging floors are usually annoying, not urgent. But they can signal a failing beam or rotted support post below.

climax.text: Jacking a sagging floor level must go slowlyâ€”1/8 inch per monthâ€”or you'll crack plaster, break pipes, and jam doors.

punchline.text: Gravity never stops pulling your house down.

quiz.question: Why must a sagging floor be raised back to level very slowly?
options: Raising it too fast can crack plaster, break pipes, and jam doors
The wood needs time to absorb moisture and expand
Building codes require a month-long inspection period

hook.text: A researcher unlocked a popular smart lock by replaying its Bluetooth signal from 50 feet away. No contact needed.

buildup.text: Smart locks communicate via Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, or Z-Wave. Each protocol has known vulnerabilities if poorly implemented.

discovery.text: Replay attacks capture a lock's handshake and retransmit it. Locks without rolling codes accept the same signal twice.

twist.text: A dead battery locks you out. Unlike a deadbolt, a smart lock's security depends on power and software updates.

climax.text: Quality smart locks use AES-128 encryption and rolling codes. Most buyers pick the cheapest without checking.

punchline.text: A smart lock is only as smart as its encryption.

quiz.question: What is a replay attack on a smart lock?
options: Capturing and retransmitting the lock's wireless handshake signal
Physically picking the emergency keyhole
Overloading the lock's processor with commands

topics.title: Lithium Battery Fires in Your Home

hook.text: Lithium-ion batteries power phones, laptops, and scooters. When they fail, they burn at 600Â°C and water won't help.

buildup.text: Thermal runaway starts when a damaged cell overheats. One cell's heat triggers the next in a chain reaction.

discovery.text: A swelling battery is the first warning. If your phone or laptop case bulges, the cell is off-gassing and may fail.

twist.text: E-bike and scooter batteries cause outsized fires due to cheap third-party chargers and larger, more energetic packs.

climax.text: Fire departments say: never charge lithium batteries overnight, use only OEM chargers, and avoid flammable surfaces.

punchline.text: The battery in your pocket can burn your house down.

quiz.question: What is the first visible warning sign of a failing lithium battery?
options: Swelling or bulging of the battery or device case
A clicking sound when charging
The device taking longer to charge

topics.title: Why Your Water Heater Could Explode

hook.text: A water heater without a working pressure relief valve is a bomb. MythBusters launched one through a two-story building.

buildup.text: Water heaters heat water in a sealed tank. As water heats, it expands and pressure builds continuously.

discovery.text: The temperature-pressure relief valve opens at 150 PSI or 210Â°F, releasing water before pressure goes critical.

twist.text: TPR valves corrode and stick closed over time. Homeowners are supposed to test them annually, but almost nobody does.

climax.text: If the thermostat fails and the TPR valve sticks, steam builds until the tank rupturesâ€”with explosive force.

punchline.text: One stuck valve turns hot water into a rocket.

quiz.question: What safety device prevents a water heater from exploding?
options: The temperature-pressure relief (TPR) valve
An automatic shut-off thermostat
A pressure-reducing regulator on the supply line

hook.text: A garage door spring holds 200+ pounds of tension. When it snaps, the released energy can break bones or be fatal.

buildup.text: Garage doors weigh 130-400 lbs. Torsion springs above the door counterbalance this weight so the opener barely works.

discovery.text: Springs have a rated life of about 10,000 cyclesâ€”roughly 7-10 years of daily use. They fatigue and fail without warning.

twist.text: DIY spring replacement is the most dangerous common home repair. The springs are under lethal tension during adjustment.

climax.text: Pro replacement costs $150-$300. ERs treat thousands of garage-spring injuries yearly from DIY attempts gone wrong.

punchline.text: The most dangerous thing in your garage isn't the car.

quiz.question: Why is DIY garage door spring replacement especially dangerous?
options: The springs are under lethal tension during adjustment
The springs contain toxic lubricants
The door must be held manually while working

hook.text: Most earthquake damage comes not from shaking but from houses sliding off foundations. The fix costs under $5,000.

buildup.text: Older homes sit on foundations by gravity aloneâ€”the wooden frame rests on concrete without any physical connection.

discovery.text: Seismic retrofitting bolts the sill plate to the concrete foundation. Plywood bracing reinforces the cripple walls.

twist.text: Unreinforced brick and stone is the deadliest building type in quakes. Bricks have no tensile strengthâ€”they crumble.

climax.text: Cities like San Francisco now mandate soft-story retrofits for older apartments, preventing collapses in future quakes.

punchline.text: The house survived the shakeâ€”then slid off its base.

quiz.question: How does seismic retrofitting primarily protect a house?
options: By bolting the wooden frame to the concrete foundation
By making the walls flexible enough to sway
By installing shock absorbers under the floor

topics.title: Solar Panel Fires Are Hard to Fight

hook.text: Firefighters sometimes let solar-panel homes burn because panels can't be shut offâ€”they generate power in any light.

buildup.text: Solar panels produce DC power in daylight even with the inverter off. The main breaker can't stop the panels.

discovery.text: Water on energized DC wiring risks electrocution. Firefighters can't safely cut vents through a panel-covered roof.

twist.text: Rapid shutdown systems, required since 2017, de-energize panel wiring in 30 seconds, making rooftop firefighting safer.

climax.text: Arc faults in panel wiring cause most solar fires. Modern detectors shut down the affected string before fire starts.

punchline.text: Panels that never turn off create fires that can't be fought.

quiz.question: Why can't firefighters simply cut power to rooftop solar panels?
options: Panels generate electricity whenever light hits them, regardless of switches
Solar panel wiring is buried inside the roof structure
The inverter locks out emergency shutoff during a fire
